name: InpharmD
headline: We provide a curated, evidence- based answer to any clinical question.
description:
Every hospital hires clinical pharmacists to answer clinical questions from doctors. 

They outsource this to us because we’re more efficient.

## What is **InpharmD™**?
Literature searching is tedious. InpharmD™ is here to help.
![](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/Graphics.png)
Clinical pharmacists can ask any question, anytime, from anywhere, and we’ll perform a custom literature search.
(And a _**32%**_ chance it’s already been asked.)
![](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/Ourstory_Icon_One.png)

Clinical Pharmacist Hours Saved

# 4x +
ROI
![](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/Ourstory_Icon_Three.png)
# 100%
Customer Satisfaction Rate

_**Author:** Tai Huynh, PharmD, BCPS + InpharmD™ AI_
### INTRODUCTION BY INPHARMD™ RESEARCHER
Evidence for use of epoprostenol in maintaining CRRT patency is conflicting as to whether a significant difference in circuit lifespan exists between epoprostenol and other anticoagulant agents; however, bleeding rates tend to be lower with epoprostenol, when used at a rate of 4-5 ng/kg/min. No differences in mortality, hypotension, or thrombosis rates have been observed. 
  * [Background](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#background0>)
  * [Literature Review](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#literature-review0>)
  * [References](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#references0>)


A 2023 systematic review and meta-analysis analyzed the efficacy of prostacyclin-based anticoagulation strategies in critically ill patients requiring extracorporeal support. The analysis incorporated data from 17 studies, encompassing 1,333 patients, the majority of whom were adults undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), with a smaller subset receiving molecular adsorbent recirculating system therapy. The pooled analysis showed no statistically significant difference in circuit lifespan between the prostacyclin and control groups (mean difference 2.5 hours; 95% confidence interval [CI] -12.0 to 16.9; p= 0.74). However, bleeding events were significantly lower in the prostacyclin-treated cohort (9.5% vs. 17.1%; odds ratio [OR] -1.14; 95% CI -1.91 to -0.37; p<0.001), whereas no significant differences were observed in thrombosis rates (3.6% vs. 2.2%; p= 0.35), hypotension (13.4% vs. 11.0%; p=0.40), or mortality (26.3% vs. 32.7%; p= 0.10). A comprehensive risk-of-bia...

_**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Epoprostenol in Maintaining CRRT Patency
## Introduction
Epoprostenol, a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation, has been explored for its utility in maintaining the patency of continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) circuits. It is particularly considered in patients at high risk of thrombosis or when other anticoagulation strategies are contraindicated.
## Evidence Summary
### Clinical Studies and Reports
  * **Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs):** Limited direct RCT evidence exists specifically evaluating epoprostenol for CRRT patency. Some small RCTs and observational studies suggest benefits in improving circuit life compared to placebo or standard care.
  * **Case Series and Case Reports:** Various case studies demonstrate successful use of epoprostenol in maintaining patency with minimal bleeding complications, even in patients at high bleeding risk.
  * **Mechanistic Studies:** In vitro studies support epoprostenol's ability to inhibit platelet function and reduce thrombus formation in extracorporeal circuits.


### Comparative Studies
Compared to heparin and citrate, epoprostenol offers an alternative with a potentially favorable bleeding profile, especially useful in patients with contraindications to systemic anticoagulation.
### Guidelines and Expert Opinions
  * Some nephrology and critical care guidelines consider epoprostenol as an option for CRRT anticoagulation, particularly in patients with increased bleeding risks.
  * Expert consensus often recommends individualized approaches depending on patient-specific thrombotic and bleeding risks.


## Conclusion
While the evidence base for epoprostenol in maintaining CRRT patency is not extensive, available reports and studies indicate it as a viable option under certain clinical conditions. Further large-scale RCTs are needed to establish definitive efficacy and safety profiles.

_**Author:** Julie Patel, PharmD, BCPS + InpharmD™ AI_
### INTRODUCTION BY INPHARMD™ RESEARCHER
Recent meta-analyses and pharmacoeconomics studies have found baloxavir to be more effective and less costly than oseltamivir. Baloxavir showed superiority over oseltamivir in reducing influenza viral titers and viral RNA loads (p<0.001) and similar safety profiles, although baloxavir had a lower incidence of nausea (p= 0.03). Baloxavir led to shorter hospitalization periods in the inpatient setting (p= 0.01), though mortality outcomes were comparable. However, benefits seem to be isolated to... 
  * [Background](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#background1>)
  * [Literature Review](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#literature-review1>)
  * [References](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#references1>)


In a 2024 systematic review and meta analysis, efficacy and safety of baloxavir was compared against oseltamivir in patients with influenza virus. Two randomized trials (N= 1,624 outpatients) and two retrospective trials (N= 874 inpatients) were assessed for mortality, hospital length of stay, illness duration and viral load, and treatment adverse events. In outpatients, no deaths occurred with either baloxavir or oseltamivir, and illness duration was comparable between groups; however, baloxavir was superior in influenza virus titer reduction (p<0.001), viral RNA load reduction (p<0.001), and was more tolerable (p= 0.03) compared to oseltamivir. In inpatients, baloxavir patients had a lower hospitalization period (p= 0.01), though mortality outcomes were similar. Based on these findings, baloxavir use may be safer and more efficacious than oseltamivir for treatment of influenza, though more data is required to confirm these findings. _**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Comparison between Xofluza (baloxavir) and Tamiflu (oseltamivir)
Feature | Xofluza (baloxavir) | Tamiflu (oseltamivir)  
---|---|---  
**Mechanism of Action** | Inhibits the cap-dependent endonuclease activity of the influenza virus polymerase, interfering with viral RNA transcription. | Inhibits the neuraminidase enzyme, preventing the release of new viral particles from infected cells.  
**Dosage Form** | Single oral dose. | Oral capsules or liquid suspension, typically taken twice daily for five days.  
**Onset of Action** | Reduces symptoms about 1-2 days faster if started within 48 hours of symptom onset. | Reduces symptoms about 1-2 days faster if started within 48 hours of symptom onset.  
**Indications** | Treatment of acute uncomplicated influenza in patients aged 12 years and older. | Treatment and prevention of influenza in individuals one year and older.  
**Adverse Effects** | Nausea, diarrhea, bronchitis. | Nausea, vomiting, headache.  
**Unique Aspects** | Single-dose treatment; newer mechanism of action may be effective against certain resistant influenza strains. | More established and widely used; available in a prophylactic form for influenza prevention.  
InpharmD's Answer GPT's Answer
_**Author:** Kevin Shin, PharmD, BCPS + InpharmD™ AI_
### INTRODUCTION BY INPHARMD™ RESEARCHER
The International Anesthesia Research Society on postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) states that intravenous (IV) fosaprepitant 150 mg is more effective than ondansetron and may help prevent postoperative emesis in high-risk surgeries (e.g., neurosurgery or gastric surgery). A meta-analysis suggests moderate-certainty evidence for IV fosaprepitant as a single prophylactic anti-emetic for PONV. 
  * [Background](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#background2>)
  * [Literature Review](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#literature-review2>)
  * [References](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#references2>)


International Anesthesia Research Society guidelines report intravenous (IV) fosaprepitant 150 mg is more effective than ondansetron, which is reported to be more effective than metoclopramide 10 mg IV and dexmedetomidine. NK1 receptor antagonists, including IV fosaprepitant, may be useful prophylaxis when postoperative emesis is highly undesirable, such as in gastric and neurosurgery. [1] A 2020 network meta-analysis (NMA) ranks antiemetics on efficacy and safety as monotherapy and in combinations in preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) within 24 hours postoperatively. The NMA included 585 studies (N = 97,516 randomized participants, a median sample size of 100), primarily conducted in Asia (51%), Europe (25%), and North America (16%), with a mean age of 42 years. Most participants were women (83%), had American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I or II (70%), received perioperative opioids (88%), and underwent gynecologic (32%) or gastrointestinal...

_**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Fosaprepitant for Prevention of Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting
## Overview
Fosaprepitant, an antagonist of neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptors, is utilized in managing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Recent studies and clinical guidelines have considered its role in preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV).
## Key Literature and Recommendations
  * **Studies:** Recent clinical trials have demonstrated the efficacy of Fosaprepitant in reducing the incidence and severity of PONV. A study published in _Anesthesia & Analgesia_ showed that Fosaprepitant significantly reduced PONV compared to a placebo.
  * **Guidelines:** The American Society of Anesthesiologists endorses considering NK1 receptor antagonists like Fosaprepitant as part of a multimodal approach for patients at high risk of PONV.
  * **Clinical Trials:** Randomized controlled trials have established the safety and tolerability of Fosaprepitant, with a favorable profile compared to traditional antiemetics.


## Conclusion
Fosaprepitant represents a promising option in the prophylactic management of PONV, particularly for patients at high risk. Its inclusion in multimodal antiemetic regimens is supported by emerging research and expert recommendations.

_**Author:** Dena Homayounieh, PharmD, BCPS + InpharmD™ AI_
### INTRODUCTION BY INPHARMD™ RESEARCHER
Available evidence suggests that lacosamide is safe and well-tolerated as an intravenous (IV) push at dosages up to 400 mg (see Tables 1-8). However, the identified studies are limited by factors such as retrospective design, lack of efficacy outcomes, and small sample sizes. Notably, lacosamide’s prescribing information allows rapid infusions lasting 15 minutes in adults and 30 minutes in children, though it does not provide specific guidance on IV push administration. 
  * [Background](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#background3>)
  * [Literature Review](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#literature-review3>)
  * [References](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#references3>)


A 2022 thesis evaluating the impact of intravenous (IV) push lacosamide on efficiency in the provision of patient care evaluated the institutional IV push policy after the addition of lacosamide. Patients aged 17 years and older were allowed to be administered doses of 400 mg or less via IV push at a rate of 80 mg/min; doses greater than 400 mg, due to lacking data for IV push administration, were excluded and would be continued to be administered as an IV piggyback (IVPB). Data for IV push lacosamide in the pediatric population at the time of publishing was nonexistent, and thus patients less than 17 years of age were excluded from the protocol. Blood pressure and heart rate readings were taken within 2 hours of administration. In total, 49 patients received IV push lacosamide with an average dose of 153 mg. Of 178 administrations with a BP reading, 8 (4.5%) had reported hypotension, with 1 (0.6%) requiring intervention; the number of patients experiencing hypotension and experienc...

_**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Literature Supporting IV Push Lacosamide
## 1. Study on Efficacy and Safety of Intravenous Lacosamide
**Reference:** Smith, J., et al. (2020). "Efficacy and Safety of Intravenous Lacosamide in Acute Seizure Management". _Journal of Clinical Neurology_ , 45(3), 123-130.
**Summary:** This study evaluated the efficacy and safety of IV push lacosamide in patients with acute seizures. The findings suggest that IV lacosamide is both effective and well-tolerated in emergency settings.
## 2. Rapid Administration Protocol for Lacosamide
**Reference:** Kumar, L., & Zhang, R. (2019). "Rapid Administration Protocol for IV Lacosamide". _Seizure: European Journal of Epilepsy_ , 28, 45-50.
**Summary:** The authors explore a protocol for the rapid administration of IV lacosamide. They conclude that it can be administered safely in a shorter duration without compromising patient safety.
## 3. Review Article on IV Lacosamide for Seizure Control
**Reference:** Lee, A., et al. (2021). "Intravenous Lacosamide in the Treatment of Seizures: A Review". _Epilepsy Research_ , 98, 217-225.
**Summary:** This review consolidates evidence on the use of IV lacosamide, highlighting its role in acute seizure control and discussing optimal dosing strategies.
## 4. Case Series on Emergency Use of IV Lacosamide
**Reference:** Patel, M., & Gomez, S. (2022). "Emergency Department Utilization of IV Lacosamide: A Case Series". _Emergency Medicine Journal_ , 34(7), 456-460.
**Summary:** A series of case reports detailing successful use of IV lacosamide in the emergency department setting, illustrating its potential benefits in urgent care situations.

_**Author:** Neil Patel, PharmD, BCPS + InpharmD™ AI_
### INTRODUCTION BY INPHARMD™ RESEARCHER
The lack of IV access can pose safety concerns, particularly in cases of nitroglycerin overexposure resulting in hypotension, as the recommended treatment involves administration of IV fluids. If IV access is unavailable, then caution is advised to ensure that patients in the EMS or urgent care receive an appropriate dose of nitroglycerin. The benefits of prehospital sublingual nitroglycerin in the EMS setting appear minimal at best, with one chart review demonstrating a clinically signifi... 
  * [Background](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#background4>)
  * [Literature Review](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#literature-review4>)
  * [References](https://www.inpharmd.com/<#references4>)


A 2013 retrospective cohort analysis examined the safety of a high-dose sublingual nitroglycerin protocol for patients experiencing acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) in the prehospital setting. Conducted using data from a single large Emergency Medical Services (EMS) agency over a six-month period, the investigation reviewed 95 instances of multiple simultaneous nitroglycerin (MSN) tablets administration by EMS providers among 75 patients. Vital signs immediately before and after MSN administration were analyzed to determine changes in systolic blood pressure (SBP), with hypotension defined as SBP <100 mmHg. Doses were stratified based on regional EMS guidelines, which recommended either two tablets (0.8 mg) for SBP >160 mmHg or three tablets (1.2 mg) for SBP >200 mmHg, administered every five minutes as needed. The analysis excluded cases with incomplete vital signs documentation and assessed each administration as a separate event. Findings demonstrated a mean reduction in ...

_**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Sublingual Nitroglycerin in EMS/Urgent Care
## Benefits
  * **Rapid Onset:** Sublingual nitroglycerin acts quickly, providing rapid relief of chest pain associated with angina or myocardial infarction.
  * **Ease of Administration:** It is easy to administer, especially in pre-hospital settings, as it does not require complex preparation or IV access.
  * **Improved Oxygen Supply:** It dilates coronary arteries, improving blood flow and oxygen delivery to the heart muscle.
  * **Reduced Myocardial Oxygen Demand:** It decreases preload and afterload, reducing the heart's workload and oxygen demand.


## Safety Risks without IV Access
  * **Hypotension Risk:** Without IV access, managing sudden drops in blood pressure can be challenging, as intravenous fluids cannot be administered promptly.
  * **Lack of Immediate Reversal:** If adverse effects occur, such as severe hypotension or bradycardia, there might be delays in administering countermeasures like IV medications.
  * **Limited Monitoring:** Without IV access, continuous monitoring and rapid intervention for potential complications are limited.
  * **Patient Specific Factors:** Patients with concurrent conditions such as dehydration or on medications like phosphodiesterase inhibitors are at increased risk without a safety net of IV access.


## Find answers, not documents.
#### Before InpharmD™
![BeforeTime](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/Time_Red.png)
Your team spends hours per week cobbling together literature from different studies, many behind paywalls, leaving little time for action. 
![BeforeTime](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/PT_Opportunities_Red.png)
TI opportunities are discovered (or presented by third parties) months after the fact, resulting in costly missed savings. 
![BeforeTime](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/Decisions_Red.png)
Decisions may be made without a complete picture, or pushed out while gathering consensus. 
#### After InpharmD™
![BeforeTime](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/Time_Green.png)
InpharmD™ delivers customized, actionable drug information in real time, so you can focus on execution. 
![BeforeTime](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/PT_Opportunities_Green.png)
Your team stays informed immediately when new data emerges or prices change, and you’ll always be the first to know when any changes impact your formulary. 
![BeforeTime](https://inpharmd-asset.s3.amazonaws.com/web/Decisions_Green.png)
With InpharmD™, your team can make faster, more informed decisions and move forward with confidence.

_**Author:** Tai Huynh, PharmD, BCPS + InpharmD™ AI_
### INTRODUCTION BY INPHARMD™ RESEARCHER
Evidence for use of epoprostenol in maintaining CRRT patency is conflicting as to whether a significant difference in circuit lifespan exists between epoprostenol and other anticoagulant agents; however, bleeding rates tend to be lower with epoprostenol, when used at a rate of 4-5 ng/kg/min. No differences in mortality, hypotension, or thrombosis rates have been observed. 
  * Background⟨5⟩
  * Literature Review⟨6⟩
  * References⟨7⟩


A 2023 systematic review and meta-analysis analyzed the efficacy of prostacyclin-based anticoagulation strategies in critically ill patients requiring extracorporeal support. The analysis incorporated data from 17 studies, encompassing 1,333 patients, the majority of whom were adults undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), with a smaller subset receiving molecular adsorbent recirculating system therapy. The pooled analysis showed no statistically significant difference in circuit lifespan between the prostacyclin and control groups (mean difference 2.5 hours; 95% confidence interval [CI] -12.0 to 16.9; p= 0.74). However, bleeding events were significantly lower in the prostacyclin-treated cohort (9.5% vs. 17.1%; odds ratio [OR] -1.14; 95% CI -1.91 to -0.37; p<0.001), whereas no significant differences were observed in thrombosis rates (3.6% vs. 2.2%; p= 0.35), hypotension (13.4% vs. 11.0%; p=0.40), or mortality (26.3% vs. 32.7%; p= 0.10). _**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Epoprostenol in Maintaining CRRT Patency
## Introduction
Epoprostenol, a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation, has been explored for its utility in maintaining the patency of continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) circuits. It is particularly considered in patients at high risk of thrombosis or when other anticoagulation strategies are contraindicated.
## Evidence Summary
### Clinical Studies and Reports
  * **Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs):** Limited direct RCT evidence exists specifically evaluating epoprostenol for CRRT patency. Some small RCTs and observational studies suggest benefits in improving circuit life compared to placebo or standard care.
  * **Case Series and Case Reports:** Various case studies demonstrate successful use of epoprostenol in maintaining patency with minimal bleeding complications, even in patients at high bleeding risk.
  * **Mechanistic Studies:** In vitro studies support epoprostenol's ability to inhibit platelet function and reduce thrombus formation in extracorporeal circuits.


### Comparative Studies
Compared to heparin and citrate, epoprostenol offers an alternative with a potentially favorable bleeding profile, especially useful in patients with contraindications to systemic anticoagulation.
### Guidelines and Expert Opinions
  * Some nephrology and critical care guidelines consider epoprostenol as an option for CRRT anticoagulation, particularly in patients with increased bleeding risks.
  * Expert consensus often recommends individualized approaches depending on patient-specific thrombotic and bleeding risks.


## Conclusion
While the evidence base for epoprostenol in maintaining CRRT patency is not extensive, available reports and studies indicate it as a viable option under certain clinical conditions. Further large-scale RCTs are needed to establish definitive efficacy and safety profiles.

Recent meta-analyses and pharmacoeconomics studies have found baloxavir to be more effective and less costly than oseltamivir. Baloxavir showed superiority over oseltamivir in reducing influenza viral titers and viral RNA loads (p<0.001) and similar safety profiles, although baloxavir had a lower incidence of nausea (p= 0.03). Baloxavir led to shorter hospitalization periods in the inpatient setting (p= 0.01), though mortality outcomes were comparable. However, benefits seem to be isolated to... 
  * Background⟨9⟩

In a 2024 systematic review and meta analysis, efficacy and safety of baloxavir was compared against oseltamivir in patients with influenza virus. Two randomized trials (N= 1,624 outpatients) and two retrospective trials (N= 874 inpatients) were assessed for mortality, hospital length of stay, illness duration and viral load, and treatment adverse events. In outpatients, no deaths occurred with either baloxavir or oseltamivir, and illness duration was comparable between groups; however, baloxavir was superior in influenza virus titer reduction (p<0.001), viral RNA load reduction (p<0.001), and was more tolerable (p= 0.03) compared to oseltamivir. In inpatients, baloxavir patients had a lower hospitalization period (p= 0.01), though mortality outcomes were similar. Based on these findings, baloxavir use may be safer and more efficacious than oseltamivir for treatment of influenza, though more data is required to confirm these findings. _**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Comparison between Xofluza (baloxavir) and Tamiflu (oseltamivir)
Feature | Xofluza (baloxavir) | Tamiflu (oseltamivir)  
---|---|---  
**Mechanism of Action** | Inhibits the cap-dependent endonuclease activity of the influenza virus polymerase, interfering with viral RNA transcription. | Inhibits the neuraminidase enzyme, preventing the release of new viral particles from infected cells.  
**Dosage Form** | Single oral dose. | Oral capsules or liquid suspension, typically taken twice daily for five days.  
**Onset of Action** | Reduces symptoms about 1-2 days faster if started within 48 hours of symptom onset. | Reduces symptoms about 1-2 days faster if started within 48 hours of symptom onset.  
**Indications** | Treatment of acute uncomplicated influenza in patients aged 12 years and older. | Treatment and prevention of influenza in individuals one year and older.  
**Adverse Effects** | Nausea, diarrhea, bronchitis. | Nausea, vomiting, headache.  
**Unique Aspects** | Single-dose treatment; newer mechanism of action may be effective against certain resistant influenza strains. | More established and widely used; available in a prophylactic form for influenza prevention.

_**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Fosaprepitant for Prevention of Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting
## Overview
Fosaprepitant, an antagonist of neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptors, is utilized in managing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Recent studies and clinical guidelines have considered its role in preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV).
## Key Literature and Recommendations
  * **Studies:** Recent clinical trials have demonstrated the efficacy of Fosaprepitant in reducing the incidence and severity of PONV. A study published in _Anesthesia & Analgesia_ showed that Fosaprepitant significantly reduced PONV compared to a placebo.
  * **Guidelines:** The American Society of Anesthesiologists endorses considering NK1 receptor antagonists like Fosaprepitant as part of a multimodal approach for patients at high risk of PONV.
  * **Clinical Trials:** Randomized controlled trials have established the safety and tolerability of Fosaprepitant, with a favorable profile compared to traditional antiemetics.


## Conclusion
Fosaprepitant represents a promising option in the prophylactic management of PONV, particularly for patients at high risk. Its inclusion in multimodal antiemetic regimens is supported by emerging research and expert recommendations.

Data for IV push lacosamide in the pediatric population at the time of publishing was nonexistent, and thus patients less than 17 years of age were excluded from the protocol. Blood pressure and heart rate readings were taken within 2 hours of administration. In total, 49 patients received IV push lacosamide with an average dose of 153 mg. # Literature Supporting IV Push Lacosamide
## 1. Study on Efficacy and Safety of Intravenous Lacosamide
**Reference:** Smith, J., et al. (2020). "Efficacy and Safety of Intravenous Lacosamide in Acute Seizure Management". _Journal of Clinical Neurology_ , 45(3), 123-130.
**Summary:** This study evaluated the efficacy and safety of IV push lacosamide in patients with acute seizures. The findings suggest that IV lacosamide is both effective and well-tolerated in emergency settings.
## 2. Rapid Administration Protocol for Lacosamide
**Reference:** Kumar, L., & Zhang, R. (2019). "Rapid Administration Protocol for IV Lacosamide". _Seizure: European Journal of Epilepsy_ , 28, 45-50.
**Summary:** The authors explore a protocol for the rapid administration of IV lacosamide. They conclude that it can be administered safely in a shorter duration without compromising patient safety.
## 3. Review Article on IV Lacosamide for Seizure Control
**Reference:** Lee, A., et al. (2021). "Intravenous Lacosamide in the Treatment of Seizures: A Review". _Epilepsy Research_ , 98, 217-225.
**Summary:** This review consolidates evidence on the use of IV lacosamide, highlighting its role in acute seizure control and discussing optimal dosing strategies.
## 4. Case Series on Emergency Use of IV Lacosamide
**Reference:** Patel, M., & Gomez, S. (2022). "Emergency Department Utilization of IV Lacosamide: A Case Series". _Emergency Medicine Journal_ , 34(7), 456-460.
**Summary:** A series of case reports detailing successful use of IV lacosamide in the emergency department setting, illustrating its potential benefits in urgent care situations.

_**Author:** Open AI GPT_
# Sublingual Nitroglycerin in EMS/Urgent Care
## Benefits
  * **Rapid Onset:** Sublingual nitroglycerin acts quickly, providing rapid relief of chest pain associated with angina or myocardial infarction.
  * **Ease of Administration:** It is easy to administer, especially in pre-hospital settings, as it does not require complex preparation or IV access.
  * **Improved Oxygen Supply:** It dilates coronary arteries, improving blood flow and oxygen delivery to the heart muscle.
  * **Reduced Myocardial Oxygen Demand:** It decreases preload and afterload, reducing the heart's workload and oxygen demand.


## Safety Risks without IV Access
  * **Hypotension Risk:** Without IV access, managing sudden drops in blood pressure can be challenging, as intravenous fluids cannot be administered promptly.
  * **Lack of Immediate Reversal:** If adverse effects occur, such as severe hypotension or bradycardia, there might be delays in administering countermeasures like IV medications.
  * **Limited Monitoring:** Without IV access, continuous monitoring and rapid intervention for potential complications are limited.
  * **Patient Specific Factors:** Patients with concurrent conditions such as dehydration or on medications like phosphodiesterase inhibitors are at increased risk without a safety net of IV access.

generated_description:
InpharmD is a healthcare venture based in Atlanta, GA, founded in 2018 as part of Y Combinator’s W21 batch. The company has a clear mission: to provide curated, evidence-based answers to clinical questions, making it easier for healthcare professionals to get critical information quickly. Typically, hospitals employ clinical pharmacists to field these questions, but InpharmD offers a more efficient outsourced solution.

The platform allows clinical pharmacists to pose any clinical question at any time and receive tailored literature searches and responses, greatly reducing the time spent on research—which can often take hours. In fact, InpharmD has already saved over 94,000 clinical pharmacist hours.

With a small but impactful team of 16 employees, InpharmD is leveraging artificial intelligence to enhance the speed and accuracy of medical literature searches. To date, they are trusted by more than 20,000 healthcare providers, including physicians, nurse practitioners, and pharmacists.

The company’s technology is particularly relevant in the fields of telemedicine and B2B services, as it addresses the urgent need for rapid access to reliable clinical information. 

Led by Jared Friedman as Group Partner, InpharmD simplifies the research process, allowing healthcare practitioners to focus more on patient care rather than getting lost in journals and paywalls. As a burgeoning tool in the medical community, it stands out for its commitment to improving the workflow of clinical professionals.

InpharmD embodies the transformation we often discuss in healthcare—a shift that prioritizes actionable advice over sifting through endless documents. If you’re looking for evidence-based answers without the hassle, you might just find your new favorite tool at their [website](https://www.inpharmd.com).
